chapter.para: The ECB Disk IO v3 allows you to connect up to 2 floppy drives of nearly any type, and up to 2 IDE hard drive-like devices. The hard drive-like devices could be mechanical hard drives, or compact flash interface devices. The hard drive is partitioned into numerous 8 meg chunks.

The Theory of Operation cannot hope to fully explain the entire board, but at least some helpful notes will be provided. Generally this should aim to exceed a simple list of features, without going into design detail. A good analogy is there is a physical walkthru at the start of the construction section, this section is more of a conceptual or theoretical walkthru.
Typical format: Project part ID, quantity if not one, model name, commentary if any, suppliers listed by supplier, item number, approx qty 1 cost, supplier comment

listitem.para: C1-C16 qty 16 ceramic disk capacitor 0.1 uF 5.08mm lead spacing
P1 ECB connector DIN 41612 right angle
RR1 bussed resistor array 1 kOhm, 9 pin aka 8 resistors
Use 150 Ohm or 330 Ohm resistor array for older drives that have 150 Ohm or 300 Ohm terminators.
Only 6 first resistors are used, so 7 pin or (more common) 8 pin arrays can be used instead.
Make sure to align pin 1 properly.
Also it is possible to use 10 pin arrays, with 10th pin cut just by the package body.
Socket pin type selection is a hotly contested personal choice.
Gold plate is less mechanically durable than tin, more corrosion resistant than the IC pins, and more expensive
Machined pins grip the pins more tightly, which is either considered a blessing or a curse, and cost more than folded sockets
The board aesthetically looks better if you use identical type sockets on the board, unless you're intentionally trying to highlight an area of the board.
In theory, you could use orange plastic sockets for the ECB interface, blue sockets for the memory decode logic...
